recipe_def.assumptions: Assemble per BOM; parts produced via part-level routes.
recipe_def.notes: Coarse assembly route; add detailed steps later.

steps.notes: Mine mare regolith from surface
Screen and separate size fractions
Crush and grind coarse regolith to powder
Extract oxygen and produce metal byproduct via MRE

recipe_def.assumptions: Co-product metal alloy from MRE; refining not modeled.

steps.notes: Cast enclosure and heat sink components
Machine mounting surfaces and cooling channels
Braze bus bars and cooling connections
Assemble with imported power electronics and controls

recipe_def.assumptions: 180 kg high-current power supply; includes imported electronics.
recipe_def.notes: Four-step recipe for high-temperature power supply unit.

steps.notes: Cast enclosure and heat sink
Machine mounting surfaces
Assemble with imported power electronics

recipe_def.assumptions: 12 kg power conditioning module; includes imported electronics.
recipe_def.notes: Three-step recipe for power conditioning module.

recipe_def.assumptions: Assumes regolith_coarse_fraction is available; mass is conserved to within placeholder losses.
recipe_def.notes: Initial, placeholder recipe to resolve no_recipe gap for coarse_powder.
recipe_def.name: Recipe for coarse powder

steps.notes: Ball mill powder mixture to reduce particle size and achieve uniform distribution; 2% loss as dust
Dry milled powder to remove moisture; ~3% moisture loss
Screen powder to achieve desired particle size distribution; final ceramic powder mixture

recipe_def.assumptions: Assumes coarse_powder feedstock from upstream ceramic mixing; ball milled, dried, and screened for uniform composition.
recipe_def.notes: Manufacturing of ceramic powder mixture from coarse_powder feedstock. Total processing time ~13 hours. Ball milling time dominates. Used for ceramic parts and refractory production.
recipe_def.name: Recipe for ceramic_powder_mixture

steps.notes: Form ceramic insulators from alumina or porcelain powder (pressing or molding)
Dry green insulators to remove moisture
Fire ceramic insulators at 1400-1600C to achieve full density and strength
Grind or polish insulator surfaces if needed

recipe_def.assumptions: Ceramic insulators for high-voltage and high-temperature applications. Fired alumina or porcelain with high dielectric strength. 3 kg set. Used in vacuum tubes for thermionic converters and electrical equipment.
recipe_def.notes: Manufacturing of ceramic insulators. Total processing time ~19.5 hours. Critical for vacuum tube feedthroughs in thermionic power system.

steps.notes: Cast copper bus bar blanks
Machine connection holes and mounting surfaces
Assemble bus with insulators and connectors

recipe_def.assumptions: 50 kg high-current bus for furnace/reactor power distribution.
recipe_def.notes: Three-step recipe for high-current power bus.

steps.notes: Cast tubing sections and fittings
Machine fitting interfaces
Braze tube joints and fittings
Final assembly with pump and valves

recipe_def.assumptions: 60 kg cooling loop with metal tubing and brazed joints.
recipe_def.notes: Four-step recipe for thermal control cooling loop.

recipe_def.assumptions: Assemble per BOM; parts produced via part-level routes.
recipe_def.notes: Coarse assembly route; add detailed steps later.
